questions.text: Complex IV is inhibited by?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B

Topic

Information

Complex IV

Complex IV, also known as cytochrome c oxidase, is the final enzyme in the electron transport chain located in the inner mitochondrial membrane. It catalyses the transfer of electrons from cytochrome c to molecular oxygen, generating water and producing a proton gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Cyanide

Cyanide is a potent inhibitor of Complex IV. It binds to the heme group of cytochrome c oxidase and prevents the transfer of electrons to molecular oxygen, thereby blocking the electron transport chain and halting oxidative phosphorylation. Cyanide poisoning can result in rapid cell death due to the cessation of ATP production. It causes histotoxic hypoxia.

Mechanism of inhibition

Cyanide binds to the ferric (Fe3+) form of the heme group in cytochrome c oxidase and converts it to the ferrous (Fe2+) form, which has a higher affinity for oxygen. This prevents the transfer of electrons from cytochrome c to oxygen, effectively halting the electron transport chain.

Clinical significance

Cyanide poisoning can occur through inhalation, ingestion, or absorption through the skin. Symptoms of cyanide poisoning include headache, dizziness, confusion, respiratory distress, and coma. Treatment typically involves administration of antidotes such as hydroxocobalamin, which binds to cyanide and forms a stable complex that is excreted in the urine.

Use in research

Cyanide is commonly used in research as a tool to study Complex IV function and the electron transport chain. Inhibiting Complex IV with cyanide can be used to study the downstream effects of oxidative phosphorylation inhibition, such as changes in ATP production, cellular metabolism, and gene expression.

Burn Degree

 

Description

Symptoms

Management

First-degree

Affect only the epidermis (outermost layer of skin)
 

Redness, pain, and mild swelling
 

Cool compresses, pain relief medications, and aloe vera gel

Second-degree

Affect the epidermis and dermis (second layer of skin)
 

Redness, pain, blisters, and swelling
 

Cool compresses, pain relief medications, and sterile dressings to prevent infection

Third-degree

Affect all layers of the skin, including nerves and blood vessels
 

White or blackened, charred skin, no pain or sensation, and swelling
 

Emergency medical treatment, including wound cleaning, antibiotics, and skin grafting

Fourth-degree

Affect all layers of the skin and underlying tissue, including muscle, tendons, and bones

Similar to third-degree burns but with extensive tissue damage and exposed bone

Emergency medical treatment, including wound cleaning, antibiotics, and skin grafting

Storage Symptoms

Voiding Symptoms

Urgency: A sudden, strong urge to urinate that may be difficult to suppress.

Hesitancy: Difficulty initiating urination, often characterized by a delay in the start of the urinary stream

Enuresis: Involuntary leakage of urine during sleep.

Dribbling: Continued leakage of urine after the urinary stream has stopped.

Frequency: Need to urinate frequently, often more than 8 times a day.

Intermittency: Urine flow stops and starts during micturition.

Nocturia: Need to wake at night at least once to void.

Poor flow

Urgency Incontinence (UI): Involuntary urinary leakage, often large volume, immediately preceded by urgency.

Incomplete emptying: Sensation of bladder fullness persisting at the end of micturition.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a pregnant woman of age 30 who visits the dermatology outpatient department (OPD) with the following condition?
questions.explanation:
Chloasma Also known as melasma or "mask of pregnancy."
Definition Hyperpigmented patches on the skin, often on the face.
Etiology Hormonal changes, UV exposure, genetics, and other factors.
Distribution Primarily occurs on the face, especially cheeks and forehead.
Color Patches are darker than surrounding skin, can be brown or gray.
Risk Factors Pregnancy, hormonal medications, sun exposure, genetics.
Pattern Often symmetrical and well-defined patches.
Trigger Factors Sun exposure and hormonal changes can exacerbate chloasma.
Diagnosis Clinical appearance; Wood's lamp examination may help.
Treatment Sun protection (SPF), topical creams, chemical peels.
  Management can be challenging, and complete resolution is not always achieved.
Prevention Sun protection and avoiding triggers can help prevent worsening.
Psychological Impact Chloasma may lead to cosmetic concerns; it doesn't cause physical harm.
Relation to Pregnancy Often occurs during pregnancy due to hormonal changes.
  May fade after pregnancy but can persist.

questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Inheritance

X-linked recessive

Incidence

Estimated to be 1 in 100,000 to 300,000 live births

Symptoms

Neurological symptoms such as developmental delay, intellectual disability, seizures, and ataxia; muscle weakness; lactic acidosis; poor feeding; and failure to thrive

Diagnosis

Blood and urine tests, genetic testing

Treatment

Supportive care, including a high-fat, low-carbohydrate diet; thiamine supplementation; and medications to control seizures and other symptoms

Prognosis

The severity of symptoms varies widely, and the prognosis depends on the specific mutation and the age of onset. Some patients have a milder form of the disease and can live relatively normal lives with appropriate treatment, while others have severe intellectual disability and may have a reduced lifespan.

  • Repeating words or phrases immediately after hearing them
Characteristics
  • Often a symptom of neurological and psychiatric conditions like autism, schizophrenia, and dementia
Causes
  • Damage to the brain's language centers (e.g., stroke, traumatic brain injury)

Types
  • Immediate echolalia: Repeating immediately after hearing
  • Delayed echolalia: Repeating after a delay, often hours or days later
Diagnosis and Management
  • Diagnosis through observation of behavior and communication patterns

Prognosis
  • Varies depending on underlying cause and severity
  • With appropriate diagnosis and management, communication and quality of life can improve.

questions.text: What should be done next in the management of a patient who is diabetic and presents with symptoms of vomiting and abdominal pain? Upon examination, the patient displays hyperventilation, sweet breath, and low blood pressure. The blood glucose level is 320 mg/dL, and urine ketones are detected.
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - IVF and check K+

questions.text: Interpret the ECG given below.
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Supra ventricular tach

Type of Tachycardia

ECG Findings

Sinus Tachycardia

Regular rhythm, narrow QRS complex, normal P waves

Atrial Tachycardia

Regular or irregular rhythm, narrow QRS complex, abnormal P waves

Atrial Flutter

Regular or irregular rhythm, sawtooth-shaped P waves, narrow QRS complex

Atrial Fibrillation

Irregular rhythm, absent P waves, narrow QRS complex or variable

AV Nodal Reentrant Tachycardia

No P wave, pseudo R wave

Junctional Tachycardia

Regular or irregular rhythm, narrow QRS complex, inverted, or absent P waves

Ventricular Tachycardia

Regular or irregular rhythm, wide QRS complex, no discernible P waves

Torsades de Pointes

Regular or irregular rhythm, twisting QRS complexes, QT prolongation
